TailParas.Para: After days of controversy, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg released a statement on the social-media behemoth's user-data crisis, which has renewed calls for governments to better regulate tech companies that hold enormous quantities of information about their users. Saying Facebook has already taken many steps to address user privacy in recent years but also "made mistakes," he added "there's more to do, and we need to step up and do it." According to Mr. Zuckerberg, the steps will include an investigation for any abuses by developers with access to large amounts of Facebook user data. The company will audit any apps that display suspicious activity and notify users affected, he said. Later, in an interview on CNN, Mr. Zuckerberg went further, apologizing for the breach of privacy and saying he isn't sure Facebook shouldn't be regulated. His contrition is unlikely to quell the calls for him to testify before legislators in the U.S. and Europe, quiet the questions about the world's most powerful technology companies—or restore the billions of dollars of Facebook's value lost.

Following a unanimous vote to raise the benchmark federal-funds rate by a quarter-percentage point, Federal Reserve officials signaled that after next year they could pick up the pace of increases to cool economic growth. They said they expect to lift the rate two or three more times this year and three times next year from the current range of 1.5% to 1.75%. But with the new Fed outlook projecting faster growth, higher inflation and lower unemployment in the coming years, officials indicated that by 2020 rates could be at a level marking a deliberately restrictive policy for the first time in more than a decade. New Chairman Jerome Powell said they must steer between raising rates too much, which would hold inflation below the Fed's 2% target, damaging its credibility, and raising rates too slowly, which would let the economy overheat and force them to move so quickly it triggers a recession. According to the Journal's Justin Lahart, it may be possible that tax cuts and government-spending increases haven't increased the risk of overheating, but the Fed isn't about to embrace that notion. And the Journal's Greg Ip writes that the Fed's balancing act may be even more delicate than it seems: In theory, keeping inflation from exceeding the target will require a 0.9-point increase in unemployment, and since records began in 1948 a rise of that size has been accomplished only one way—through a recession.

As the Trump administration appears to be softening its stance somewhat on trade—negotiating exemptions from steel and aluminum tariffs with some U.S. trading partners—it is sharpening its sword against China, which may answer with measures of its own. U.S. trade representative Robert Lighthizertold lawmakers worried about a brewing trade war that tariffs and investment restrictions, set to be announced by President Trump today, will pressure China to better protect American intellectual property. In response, say people familiar with the matter, Beijing plans tariffs hitting U.S. agricultural exports, which would target Mr. Trump's support base: He won eight of the top 10 soybean and hog-producing states and seven of the top 10 sorghum states. China buys about a third of the U.S. soybean crop. As for the steel and aluminum tariffs set to take effect Friday, Mr. Lighthizer told lawmakers the administration is discussing exemptions with Argentina, Australia and the European Union and will soon begin talks with Brazil. Exemptions may also be in line for Canada, Mexico and South Korea, he indicated, depending on the progress of broader trade talks. Also seeking exemptions: U.S. manufacturers.

A social-media frenzy broke out in recent weeks as the Kinder egg—a chocolate with a toy inside—went on sale in the U.S., where it had long been banned. But fans quickly learned that the stateside version, called the Kinder Joy, shares only two characteristics with the beloved original, the Kinder Surprise: It is a hollow ovoid that contains a toy. Rather than chocolate, the egg is made of plastic, its chocolate taking the form of two wafer balls inside, along with a swirl of edible cream and a small plastic spoon. (The toy is in the other side of the egg; both sides are sealed.) For Kinder Surprise enthusiasts, this alternative—produced by Italy's Ferrero, maker of Nutella—serves only as a painful reminder that they are still separated from the product they love by an 80-year-old law forbidding food from containing nonedible items.

Responding to yesterday's question on the proposed measures by the Trump administration on China, Harry Howell of North Carolina wrote: "China has long taken advantage of this country with tariffs, government subsidies and by stealing costly technology. What a deal. Even though observing a rising trade deficit for years, we have gone into denial. Now that there is an administration in charge that is addressing this imbalance, and what is the response? For one, China is hunkering down, reverting to national unity with the crowning of Xi Jinping. In contrast, American political and intellectual elite continue to oppose any meaningful action. It seems only our workers understand the gravity of this problem. They voted for Trump." Catherine Learoyd of Texas said: "Not even the Chinese government can stop Chinese businessmen from playing their ancient national sport of the art of bargaining and getting the best deal. China's largest natural resource is inexpensive labor and they know how to turn that into profit. The cost of the damages from President Trump's bull in the China shop approach will go directly to the American consumer in higher prices. Good thing we all have our $1.50-per-week tax cut." And Rich Irwin of Ohio replied: "China has chosen to take the easy road and take advantage of greedy businesses and is using it to make themselves rich and powerful in the process. The hard road would be for them to develop their technology and ideas and successfully market them. I consider this short-term smart and long-term stupid."

This daily briefing is named "The 10-Point" after the nickname conferred by the editors of The Wall Street Journal on the lead column of the legendary "What's News" digest of top stories. Technically, "10-point" referred to the size of the typeface. The type is smaller now but the name lives on.
